meta.description: Crustaceans use two synergistic mechanics: Shell creatures have protective layers that absorb damage, while Molt creatures can regenerate and grow stronger over time. Combine both for maximum resilience.

cards._comment: === SHELL PREY - Defensive creatures with protective shells ===
cards.name: Hermit Crab
cards.flavorText: Hermit crabs upgrade shells as they grow, sometimes forming queues to swap in size order.

cards.name: Pea Crab
cards.flavorText: Pea crabs are tiny parasites that live inside mussels and oysters, stealing food from their host's gills.

cards.name: Sand Crab
cards.flavorText: Sand crabs filter-feed by extending feathery antennae into receding waves, facing the ocean backward.

cards.name: Fiddler Crab
cards.flavorText: Male fiddler crabs wave their oversized claw to attract mates. If lost, the other claw grows large instead.

cards.name: Porcelain Crab
cards.flavorText: Porcelain crabs aren't true crabs. They can autotomize limbs instantly to escape predators.

cards.name: Cleaner Shrimp
cards.flavorText: Cleaner shrimp set up stations where fish line up to have parasites picked off their bodies.

cards.name: Rock Crab
cards.flavorText: Rock crabs can regenerate lost limbs over several molts, regrowing claws almost to full size.

cards.name: Decorator Crab
cards.flavorText: Decorator crabs attach sponges, algae, and anemones to hooked hairs on their shells as camouflage.

cards._comment: === MOLT PREY - Creatures that regenerate and grow ===
cards.name: Ghost Shrimp
cards.flavorText: Ghost shrimp build elaborate Y-shaped burrows that aerate seafloor sediment, benefiting entire ecosystems.

cards.name: Krill
cards.flavorText: Antarctic krill swarms can weigh over 2 million tons. They sustain whales, seals, and penguins alike.

cards.name: Cherry Shrimp
cards.flavorText: Cherry shrimp are selectively bred from wild Neocaridina. Their red color comes from astaxanthin pigment.

cards.name: Glass Shrimp
cards.flavorText: Glass shrimp are nearly transparent. Internal organs are visible through their exoskeleton.

cards.name: Amphipod
cards.flavorText: Amphipods thrive everywhere from deep-sea trenches to backyard puddles. Over 10,000 species are known.

cards.name: Crawfish
cards.flavorText: Crawfish can walk forward but escape danger by flipping their tail to shoot backward at high speed.

cards.name: Bamboo Shrimp
cards.flavorText: Bamboo shrimp fan-feed by spreading specialized bristled legs into the current to catch microorganisms.

cards._comment: === HYBRID PREY - Both Shell and Molt ===
cards.name: Boxer Crab
cards.flavorText: Boxer crabs carry a sea anemone in each claw for defense. If one is lost, they split the other in two.

cards.name: Mud Crab
cards.flavorText: Mud crabs tolerate huge salinity swings, thriving in brackish mangrove estuaries worldwide.

cards.name: Horseshoe Crab
cards.flavorText: Horseshoe crabs have blue copper-based blood used to test medical equipment for bacterial contamination.

cards.name: Velvet Crab
cards.flavorText: Velvet crabs get their name from fine hair covering their shell. They are among the most aggressive UK crabs.

cards.name: Snow Crab
cards.flavorText: Snow crabs live at depths up to 1,200m in near-freezing water. Males can be twice the size of females.

cards.name: Sally Lightfoot Crab
cards.flavorText: Sally Lightfoot crabs graze algae off Galapagos lava rocks. Juveniles are black for camouflage; adults turn red.

cards.name: Slipper Lobster
cards.flavorText: Slipper lobsters lack claws entirely. Their antennae evolved into broad flat plates used for digging.

cards.name: Blue Crab
cards.flavorText: Blue crabs can swim using paddle-shaped rear legs. Males have blue claws; females have red-tipped ones.

cards.name: Stone Crab
cards.flavorText: Florida law requires harvesting only one stone crab claw and releasing the crab alive to regrow it.

cards.name: Dungeness Crab
cards.flavorText: Dungeness crabs molt up to 15 times before reaching market size. They are named after a Washington port.

cards.name: King Crab
cards.flavorText: Red king crabs have a leg span up to 1.8m. Despite their name, they have only 6 walking legs and 2 claws.

cards.name: Pistol Shrimp
cards.flavorText: A pistol shrimp's claw snap creates a cavitation bubble reaching 4,700C and producing a 218-decibel shockwave.

params.title: Choose a creature for sonic snap damage

cards.name: Spiny Lobster
cards.flavorText: Spiny lobsters migrate in single-file lines of up to 60 individuals, navigating by Earth's magnetic field.

cards.name: Giant Isopod
cards.flavorText: Giant isopods can survive 5+ years without eating. They gorge on whale falls and other deep-sea carrion.

cards.name: American Lobster
cards.flavorText: American lobsters can live over 100 years and never stop growing. The largest on record weighed 20 kg.

cards.name: Coconut Crab
cards.flavorText: Coconut crabs have the strongest grip of any crustacean, exerting force comparable to a lion's bite.

cards.name: Japanese Spider Crab
cards.flavorText: Japanese spider crabs are the largest living arthropods, with leg spans reaching 3.7 meters across.

cards.name: Mantis Shrimp
cards.flavorText: Mantis shrimp strike at 23 m/s, accelerating faster than a .22 caliber bullet. They see 12 color channels.

params.title: Choose a creature for devastating punch

cards.name: Robber Crab
cards.flavorText: Robber crabs are a land-dwelling form of coconut crab. They climb trees and have an acute sense of smell.

cards.name: Shell Shock
cards.flavorText: Crustacean shells are made of chitin reinforced with calcium carbonate, one of nature's toughest composites.

cards.name: Exoskeleton
cards.flavorText: A crustacean's exoskeleton hardens through sclerotization, a chemical process that cross-links proteins.

cards.name: Tidal Pool
cards.flavorText: Tide pools host over 100 crustacean species. Water temperature can swing 20C in a single tidal cycle.

cards.name: Pincer Assault
cards.flavorText: Crab claws generate crushing force up to 19,000 newtons per square cm through leveraged muscle geometry.

cards.name: Deep Sea Refuge
cards.flavorText: Below 200m, the aphotic zone holds crustaceans adapted to total darkness and crushing pressure.

cards.name: Crustacean Swarm
cards.flavorText: Christmas Island's annual red crab migration involves 50 million crabs marching from forest to sea.

cards.name: Shell Fragment
cards.flavorText: Discarded crustacean shells are rich in chitin, now used to make biodegradable plastics and wound dressings.

cards.name: Shed Skin
cards.flavorText: After molting, a crustacean absorbs water to expand before its new shell hardens over several hours.

cards.name: Barnacle Grip
cards.flavorText: Barnacles glue themselves with the strongest natural adhesive known, resisting forces over 5,000 lbs/sq in.

cards.name: Quick Molt
cards.flavorText: Molting is triggered by ecdysone hormone. Crustaceans often eat their old shell to reclaim the calcium.

cards.name: Chitinous Defense
cards.flavorText: Chitin is the second most abundant biopolymer on Earth after cellulose, found in all crustacean shells.

cards.name: Snap Trap
cards.flavorText: A crab's claw muscles can close 10x faster than they open, optimized for ambush-speed prey capture.

cards.name: Reef Ambush
cards.flavorText: Coral reefs shelter over 1,200 crustacean species. Many are nocturnal, hiding in crevices by day.

cards.name: Claw Lock
cards.flavorText: Crabs lock claws in territorial disputes that can last hours. The loser often autotomizes its claw to flee.
